results.title: Shipyard
results.brief_description: An outstanding early British documentary made by Rotha and sponsored by the Orient line. Remarkable for its fine photography and editing techniques especially the use of combined dissolves and superimposition to develop two associated ideas simultaneously (influenced by early Soviet filmmaking principles). Describes the building of the steamship “Orion” at Barrow-in-Furness and its economic effects on the life of the town, making particularly effective use of the local dialect (the film unit were noted for their attempt to show the working class under a positive light). Written and edited by Paul Rotha; photography by George Pocknall, Frank Bundy, Frank Goodliffe and Harry Rignold.

results.title: Shipwrecked a True Story
results.creator_credit: Bill Bennett Productions, Dick Smith Adventure and Bill Bennett
results.brief_description: On April 15th, 1978, Bill Belcher, lone yachtsman in a race from New Zealand to Australia, was shipwrecked. His self-designed and built craft was wrecked on a coral atoll some 600 kilometres from the coast of Australia. From that time, until his rescue on May 13th, Bill survived in an inflatable rubber life raft. This is the recreated story of his extraordinary experience.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Bennett Productions, Dick Smith Adventure and Bill Bennett

results.title: Ships of the desert
results.brief_description: A journey through the Middle East, from Israel to Egypt. This fascinating adventure takes you through the Judean Desert to the ancient biblical city of Jericho, across the Sinai Desert to the Dead Sea, then to the Gulf of Aqaba to scuba dive amongst the wonderful coral reefs and on to Eilat. After Jerusalem, “the focus of the law of God and the hatred of Man”, we visit a Kibbutz and travel along the Suez Canal to Cairo to marvel at the pyramids on the banks of the Nile. We then travel to Aswan, to see the incredible Aswan Dam and Abu Simbel then on to Luxor, The Valley of the Kings, and the “Tomb of Tutankhamen”.

results.title: Shipmates
results.brief_description: Emily brings her friends home to the Cape Otway Lighthouse for her twelfth birthday. Her fisherman friend Jack gives her a model of the “Loch Ard” one of the clipper ships which foundered on the coast. Jack is keen to catch the tagged fish which will win him a new boat. But the “Loch Ard” has plans of its own. Rated: G

results.title: Shipbuilding in Australia
results.brief_description: A brief history of the shipbuilding industry in Australia, and a record of the designing, building, launching and trials of an Australian ship. Includes the initial planning by the designer; the steel stockyard, building berth and fitting berth; and the slip-way where the ship is constructed and launched, and after which all the fittings such as radar, wireless, and rigging are installed. Also sea trials and handing over.

results.title: Shipbuilding I
results.brief_description: “Summary: set in port glasgow, this film describes how a systems approach can be used in the analysis of a shipyard system. a series of questions are posed and the way in which one might begin to explore them is indicated. the often encountered difficulty of reconciling opposing viewpoints in the systems approach (eg. divergence of management/worker opinions) is also highlighted. narrated by John Naughton”

results.title: Ship-Busters
results.creator_credit: Great Britain. Royal Air Force. Film Production Unit
results.brief_description: A tribute to the British Dominion Allied Squadrons of the Royal Air Force Coastal Command who took part in the campaign against German-controlled shipping along the coast of Europe during the years 1939-45. The R.A.F. in Norway during WWII.
